H0.text: Where rivers form is where active volcanoes are most likely to be found.

H1.text: Where tectonic plates meet are the most likely places where active volcanoes are found.

H2.text: Where oceans are deepest is where active volcanoes are most likely to be found.

H3.text: Active volcanoes are most likely to be found where land and water meet.

A4.text: The vast majority of the world's active volcanoes occur along plate boundaries, with the Pacific plate's Ring of Fire being the most active and widely known.

A5.text: Some volcanoes occur in the interiors of plates, and these have been variously attributed to internal plate deformation and to mantle plumes.

A6.text: Volcanoes are usually not created at transform tectonic boundaries where two tectonic plates slide past one another.

A8.text: Volcanoes that occur above subduction zones, such as Mount St. Helens, Mount Etna, and Mount Fuji, lie approximately one hundred kilometers from the trench in arcuate chains called volcanic arcs.

A9.text: Continental arcs such as the Cascade Volcanic Arc, that form along the coast of continents.
